facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 107 and 1080 of 1967 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 107 and 1080 of 1967. Appeals by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals from judgment and order dated November 16, 1966 of Mysore High Court in Sales Tax Revision Petition No. 52 of 1965 and Writ Petition No. 2349 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment and order dated November 16, 1966 of the Mysore High Court in Sales Tax Revision Petition No. 52 of 1965 and Writ Petition No. 2349 of 1965 respectly.

facts.text: Appellant was a dealer in textiles with head office at Mercara and branch at Bangalore.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was a dealer, among other things, in textiles, with its head office at Mercara and a branch at Bangalore.

facts.text: Appellant assessed to sales tax on April 29, 1965 under Mysore General Sales Tax Act, 1957 for period October 1, 1957 to March 31, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: It was assessed to sales tax on April 29, 1965 under the Mysore General Sales Tax Act, 1957, on its turnover for the period from October 1, 1957 to March 31, 1958.

facts.text: Dispute over turnover of Rs. 3,87,200 estimated as value of stock of mill cloth held by appellant on December 14, 1957 being exigible to tax.

anchor.surface_text: The question in dispute was whether the turnover of Rs. 3,87,200 estimated to be the value of the stock of mill cloth held by the Appellant on December 14, 1957 was exigible to tax.

facts.text: Appellant's contention before assessing authority: turnover related to mill cloth on which additional excise duty was not payable and not paid, exempt from sales tax.

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the Appellant before the assessing authority was that the turnover related to mill cloth on which the additional excise duty was not payable and therefore not paid and so the turnover was exempt from sales tax.

facts.text: Appellant's appeal to Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellant appealed to the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes. The appeal was dismissed.

facts.text: Appellant's further appeal to Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Its further appeal to the Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal also proved unsuccessful.

facts.text: Appellant filed revision to Mysore High Court and writ petition, both dismissed by Division Bench.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellant took the matter in revision to the Mysore High Court and it also filed a writ petition. ... A Division Bench of the High Court by a common judgment dismissed the petitions.

facts.text: Mysore Sales Tax Act, 1957 came into force on October 1, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The Mysore Sales Tax Act, 1957 hereinafter referred to as the Act, came into force on October 1, 1957.

facts.text: Additional Duties of Excise (Goods of Special Importance) Act, 1957 (58 of 1957) came into force on December 24, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Parliament passed the Additional Duties of Excise goods of special importance Act, 1957, 58 of 1957 which came into force on December 24, 1957.

facts.text: Mysore Sales Tax Amendment Ordinance 1957 (Mysore Ordinance 9 of 1957) came into force on December 14, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The Mysore Sales Tax Amendment Ordinance 1957, Mysore Ordinance 9 of 1957 came into force on December 14, 1957.

facts.text: Mysore Sales Tax Amendment Act, 1958 (Mysore Act No. 9 of 1958) replaced ordinance with retrospective effect from December 14, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The Ordinance was replaced by the Mysore Sales Tax Amendment Act, 1958 Mysore Act No. 9 of 1958 which was given retrospective effect as from December 14, 1957.

facts.text: Sub-section 5A inserted in section 5 by Amending Act No. 9 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section 5A inserted in section 5 by the Amending Act No. 9 of 1958 read as follows-

facts.text: Mysore Sales Tax Amendment Act, 1964 (Mysore Act No. 9 of 1964) substituted new sub-section 5A, deemed always to have been there.

anchor.surface_text: a further amendment was effected by the Mysore Legislature by enacting Mysore Sales Tax Amendment Act, 1963 Mysore Act No. 9 of 1964 whereby the new sub-section 5A was inserted ... The substituted sub-section, according to section 5(5) of the amending Act was deemed always to have been there.

facts.text: In Writ Petition No. 368 of 1961, Mysore High Court held section 5(5A)(a) inapplicable if excise duty not levied and paid, and Entry 8A exempted stock.

anchor.surface_text: In Writ Petition No. 368 of 1961, the Mysore High Court considered the effect of these amendments. ... The Court said that admittedly, additional excise duty was not leviable on the stock of cloth in question, The Court further held that Entry 8A of the Fifth Schedule completely exempted the stock of cloth from the payment of any sales tax.

facts.text: Appellant's main argument before High Court: sub-section 5A levies tax on fictitious sales, beyond state power under Entry 54.

anchor.surface_text: The main argument of the Appellant before the High Court was that sub-section 5A of Section 5 as amended by Act No. 9 of 1964 purported to levy tax not on actual sales but on fictitious or deemed sales, and therefore the sub-section was bad...

facts.text: High Court overruled appellant's contention, held tax on actual sales.

anchor.surface_text: The Court over-ruled the contention and held that the tax imposed was on actual sales and not on deemed or fictitious ones.

facts.text: Appellant raised additional ground: Mysore Act No. 9 of 1964 came into force on February 27, 1964, textiles declared goods, rate limited to 2% under section 15 Central Sales Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: namely, that on February 27, 1964 the date on which the Mysore Act No. 9 of 1964 came into force textiles having become declared goods the Mysore State Legislature was competent to levy tax on sales of textiles only subject to the restrictions...

facts.text: Supreme Court permitted appellant to raise additional ground as pure question of law.

anchor.surface_text: Being a pure question of law, we permitted the Appellant to urge the ground in support of the appeals and allowed the said application.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeals with costs.

anchor.surface_text: We dismiss the appeals with costs. There will be only one hearing fee.

facts.text: Textiles became declared goods from April 1, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: It was because textiles became declared goods from April 1, 1958 that the Mysore Legislature lost its power to tax the sales of textiles at a rate higher than that specified...

anchor.surface_text: The relevant portion of Section 15 of the Central Sales Tax Act as it stood on February 27, 1964 ran as follows - Every sales tax law of a State shall, in so far as it imposes or authorises the imposition of a tax on the sale or purchase of declared goods, be subject to the following restrictions and conditions, namely - (a) the tax payable under that law in respect of any sale or purchase of such goods inside the State shall not exceed two per cent of the sale or purchase price thereof, and such tax shall not be levied at more than one stage

issues.text: whether the turnover of Rs. 3,87,200 estimated to be the value of the stock of mill cloth held by the Appellant on December 14, 1957 was exigible to tax

anchor.surface_text: The question in dispute was whether the turnover of Rs. 3,87,200 estimated to be the value of the stock of mill cloth held by the Appellant on December 14, 1957 was exigible to tax. The contention of the Appellant before the assessing authority was that the turnover related to mill cloth on which the additional excise duty was not payable and therefore not paid and so the turnover was exempt from sales tax.

issues.text: whether sub-section 5A introduced in section 5 of the Mysore General Sales Tax Act, 1957 by Act No. 9 of 1964 under which the levy was made was ultra vires the powers of Mysore Legislature and therefore void

anchor.surface_text: The Appellant took the matter in revision to the Mysore High Court and it also filed a writ petition. Its contention in the writ petition was that sub-section 5A introduced in section 5 of the Mysore General Sales Tax Act, 1957 by Act No. 9 of 1964 under which the levy was made was ultra vires the powers of Mysore Legislature and therefore void.

issues.text: whether sub-section 5A of Section 5 as amended by Act No. 9 of 1964 purported to levy tax not on actual sales but on fictitious or deemed sales, and therefore the sub-section was bad as the Legislature had no power pursuant to Entry 54 of State List to tax non-existent sales

anchor.surface_text: The main argument of the Appellant before the High Court was that sub-section 5A of Section 5 as amended by Act No. 9 of 1964 purported to levy tax not on actual sales but on fictitious or deemed sales, and therefore the sub-section was bad, as the Legislature had no power pursuant to Entry 54 of State List of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution to tax non-existent sales.

issues.text: whether on February 27, 1964 the date on which the Mysore Act No. 9 of 1964 came into force, textiles having become declared goods, the Mysore State Legislature was competent to levy tax on sales of textiles only subject to the restrictions and conditions laid down in section 15 of the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956 including that the rate of tax should not exceed two per cent, such that the retrospective levy under section 5A was bad or the rates stood modified

anchor.surface_text: Before us, counsel for the Appellant did not attack the reasoning of the High Court on any of the grounds taken in the special leave petition. The Appellant, however, sought permission by C.M.P. 4827/70 to raise an additional ground, namely, that on February 27, 1964 the date on which the Mysore Act No. 9 of 1964 came into force textiles having become declared goods the Mysore State Legislature was competent to levy tax on sales of textiles only subject to the restrictions...

anchor.surface_text: The main argument of the Appellant before the High Court was that sub-section 5A of Section 5 as amended by Act No. 9 of 1964 purported to levy tax not on actual sales but on fictitious or deemed sales, and therefore the sub-section was bad, as the Legislature had no power pursuant to Entry 54 of State List of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution to tax non-existent sales.

arguments.claim: The tax imposed was on actual sales and not on deemed or fictitious ones.

anchor.surface_text: The Court over-ruled the contention and held that the tax imposed was on actual sales and not on deemed or fictitious ones.The Court also held - It will be remembered that the Position as stated in the judgment of this Court in Writ Petition 368 of 1961 was that the total effect of the amendment was to give paramount operation or importance to sub-section 1 of Section 8 which was a categorical statement of exemptions.

arguments.claim: On February 27, 1964 the date on which the Mysore Act No. 9 of 1964 came into force textiles having become declared goods the Mysore State Legislature was competent to levy tax on sales of textiles only subject to the restrictions and conditions laid down in section 15 of the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956 including that the rate of tax should not exceed two per cent such that the retrospective levy under section 5A was bad or the rates stood modified.

anchor.surface_text: namely, that on February 27, 1964 the date on which the Mysore Act No. 9 of 1964 came into force textiles having become declared goods the Mysore State Legislature was competent to levy tax on sales of textiles only subject to the restrictions and conditions laid down in section 15 of the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956, one of the restrictions being that the rate of tax should not exceed two per cent

court_response_anchor.surface_text: on 5 5  of the Act No. 9 of 1964, the substituted sub-section  5A  was deemed to have been in the Mysore General Sales Tax Act always. The only limit

arguments.court_reasoning: Legislature competent in 1964 to retrospectively tax sales during 1957-58 when textiles not declared goods; power for past period based on power then, no fetter on retrospective levy.

arguments.claim: Act No. 9 of 1964 was retrospective in character and for enacting such a measure the Legislature must have power on the date of the enactment and that its competency at some anterior time is immaterial; relied on A Hajee Abdul Shakoor.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Appellant contended that Act No. 9 of 1964 was retrospective in character and for enacting such a measure the Legislature must have power on the date of the enactment and that its competency at some anterior time is immaterial. In other words, the contention was that if the Mysore Legislature had no power on February 27, 1964 to impose tax on sales of declared goods at a rate in excess of that specified in section 15

court_response_anchor.surface_text: sore General Sales Tax Act always. The only limit on the power of a legislature to create a fiction is that it should number transcend its power by it

arguments.court_reasoning: Proposition from precedent has no application; competence for past period depends on power possessed during that period; textiles not declared goods during assessment period.

arguments.claim: Mysore Legislature was competent in 1964 to impose tax on sales of textiles during the assessment period from October 1, 1957 to March 31, 1958 at a rate in excess of that specified in section 15 of the Central Sales Tax Act when textiles were not declared goods.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that the above proposition has any application to the case in hand. The question here is whether Mysore Legislature was competent in 1964 to impose tax on sales of textiles during the assessment period namely from October 1, 1957 to March 31, 1958 at a rate in excess of that specified in section 15 of the Central Sales Tax Act as it stood then, when textiles were not declared goods.

arguments.claim: The power of the Legislature to retrospectively levy tax has not been controverted; no fetter on power to impose sales tax on undeclared goods during assessment period.
The only limit on the power of a legislature to create a fiction is that it should not transcend its power by its creation; substituted s.5(5A) deemed always there within power for pre-1958 period.

holdings.text: imposition of sales tax on textiles at the rate specified in the Second Schedule to the Act before they became declared goods was permissible for the Legislature of Mysore

anchor.surface_text: We think that imposition of sales tax on textiles at the rate specified in the Second Schedule to the Act before they became declared goods was permissible for the Legislature of Mysore. The power of the Legislature to retrospectively levy tax has not been controverted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature's competence for retrospective levy determined by power possessed during the past assessment period when textiles were undeclared goods, not by later status

holdings.text: There was no fetter on the power of the Legislature of Mysore on February 27, 1964 in enacting a measure imposing sales tax on the turnover of undeclared goods during the assessment period at the rate specified in the 2nd Schedule to the Act
holdings.reasoning_summary: No restriction on retrospective taxation of undeclared goods at pre-declaration rates despite enactment after declaration date

holdings.text: As textiles were not declared goods before April 1, 1958, there was no inhibition on the part of the Mysore Legislature in subjecting the turnover of sales of textiles before that period to a tax higher than that specified in section 15 of the Central Sales Tax Act

anchor.surface_text: Though the goods on the sale of which tax was imposed remained the same in substance, their legal quality became different. As textiles were not declared goods before April 1, 1958, there was no inhibition on the part of the Mysore Legislature in subjecting the turnover of sales of textiles before that period to a tax higher than that specified in section 15 of the Central Sales Tax Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legal status of goods during tax period governs retrospective competence, not subsequent declaration

holdings.text: The only limit on the power of a legislature to create a fiction is that it should not transcend its power by its creation
holdings.reasoning_summary: Deeming provision valid as it operates within legislative power for pre-declaration period

holdings.text: We dismiss the appeals with costs

anchor.surface_text: We dismiss the appeals with costs. There will be only one hearing fee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All challenges to tax levy under s.5(5A) rejected, including ultra vires, fictitious sales, and retrospective competence

holdings.text: the above proposition has any application to the case in hand

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Appellant contended that Act No. 9 of 1964 was retrospective in character and for enacting such a measure the Legislature must have power on the date of the enactment and that its competency at some anterior time is immaterial. ... We do not think that the above proposition has any application to the case in hand.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished A Hajee Abdul Shakoor & Co. as involving prior constitutional assent requirement for essential goods, inapplicable here

precedents.citation: Innamuri Gopalan v. State of Andhra Pradesh 1

anchor.surface_text: Innamuri Gopalan v. State of Andhra Pradesh 1 , the Court held that before the charge created by section 5  5A   a  can companye into operation excise duty or additional excise duty should have been levied and the same number paid by the assessee. And as it companyld number have been levied if it was number leviable under law, section 5  5A   a  was inapplicable.The Court said that admittedly, additional excise duty was number leviable on the stock of cloth in question, The Court further held that Entry 8A of the Fifth Schedule companypletely exempted the stock of cloth from the payment of any sales tax. In view of the above decision of the High Court, a further amendment was effected by the Mysore Legislature by enacting Mysore Sales Tax  Amendment  Act, 1963  Mysore Act No. 9 of 1964  whereby the new sub-section  5A  was inserted in the place of the sub-section of the same number introduced by Mysore Act No. 9 of 1958.  1  14 S.T.C. 742. 9-L500 Sup.CI/72

precedents.case_name: Innamuri Gopalan v. State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: before the charge created by section 5(5A)(a) can come into operation excise duty or additional excise duty should have been levied and the same not paid by the assessee

precedents.citation: A Hajee Abdul Shakoor and Company v. State of Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: In support of this proposition, companynsel relied upon certain observations in A Hajee Abdul Shakoor and Company v. State of Madras 1  one of the, questions which this Court had to companysider in that case was whether the Madras Legislature was companypetent to enact the provisions of sub-section  1  of s. 2 of the Madras General Sales Tax  Special Provisions  Act, 1963. Hides and skins had been declared under Act LII of 1952 to be essential for the life of the companymunity. Art. 286 3  of the Constitution as it stood before its amendment by the Constitution VI Amendment Act of 1956, on September 11, 1958 provided that notlaw made by the Legislature of a State imposing or authorising the imposition of a tax on the sale or purchase of any such goods as have been declared by Parliament by law to be essential for he life of the companymunity shall have effect unless it has been reserved for the companysideration of the President and has received his assent. By August 28, 1963, when the Act was enacted by the Madras Legislature, Art. 286 3  had been amended and Act LII of 1952 had also been repealed. Consequently there was noConstitutional requirement for the Act being reserved for the assent of the President before it could be enforced. But it was contended for the petitioner there that the Act was really enacted for a period, when if passed, it had to receive the Presidents assent for its enforcement and that therefore the State Legislature could not even in 1963 enact this provision affecting the taxation law in respect of the sale or purchase of goods which were goods  1  1964 8 S.C.R. 217 at 231.

precedents.case_name: A Hajee Abdul Shakoor and Company v. State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: State Legislature was free to enact laws which would have retrospective operation and its competence to make a law for a certain past period depends on its present legislative power and not on what it possessed at the period of time when its enactment is to have operation
